articles.headline: A Guide to Big Changes for Public Service Loan Forgiveness
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of borrowers with so-called F.F.E.L. student loans, people who paid late and military members could now get credit for years of payments toward erasing their debts.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of borrowers with so-called F.F.E.L. student loans, people who paid late and military members could now get credit for years of payments toward erasing their debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Changes that the Education Department is making to the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program should help hundreds of thousands qualify for relief much sooner than they had ever hoped — if the alterations work as intended.

articles.headline: An Asylum Seeker’s Wrenching Choice: Stay on the Run or Save His Child’s Life
articles.snippet: As a humanitarian crisis grows on Poland’s border, where the government has taken a hard line on migrants, one father had to decide whether to save an ailing baby girl and risk being expelled.
articles.abstract: As a humanitarian crisis grows on Poland’s border, where the government has taken a hard line on migrants, one father had to decide whether to save an ailing baby girl and risk being expelled.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALONG THE EASTERN POLAND BORDER — The father had walked in circles in the rain-drenched Polish forest, cradling his sick daughter, delirious after three days with barely any food or water as temperatures dipped toward freezing. He was soaked, shivering and facing a terrible choice.

articles.headline: Senate Nears Agreement to Stave Off Debt Crisis Until December
articles.snippet: With a default on federal debt as little as 12 days away, Senator Mitch McConnell offered to let Democrats temporarily lift the borrowing limit.
articles.abstract: With a default on federal debt as little as 12 days away, Senator Mitch McConnell offered to let Democrats temporarily lift the borrowing limit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats and Republicans neared agreement as they met into the early morning hours Thursday to temporarily pull the nation from the brink of a debt default. The deal would punt their showdown on raising the federal borrowing limit to December after Republicans bowed to pressure to stave off immediate fiscal calamity.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: Report Cites New Details of Trump Pressure on Justice Dept. Over Election
articles.snippet: A Senate panel fleshed out how Donald Trump pursued his plan to install a loyalist as acting attorney general to pursue unfounded reports of fraud.
articles.abstract: A Senate panel fleshed out how Donald Trump pursued his plan to install a loyalist as acting attorney general to pursue unfounded reports of fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even by the standards of President Donald J. Trump, it was an extraordinary Oval Office showdown. On the agenda was Mr. Trump’s desire to install a loyalist as acting attorney general to carry out his demands for more aggressive investigations into his baseless claims of election fraud.

articles.headline: The Future Farmers of France Are Tech Savvy, and Want Weekends Off
articles.snippet: An unconventional school wants to attract a new crowd to French agriculture, and help farms earn a profit.
articles.abstract: An unconventional school wants to attract a new crowd to French agriculture, and help farms earn a profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Tesla Will Move Its Headquarters to Austin, Texas, in Blow to California
articles.snippet: Elon Musk announced the move at the company’s annual shareholder meeting, hosted at a factory Tesla is building near Austin.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk announced the move at the company’s annual shareholder meeting, hosted at a factory Tesla is building near Austin.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tesla will move its headquarters from California to Austin, Texas, where it is building a new factory, its chief executive, Elon Musk, said at the company’s annual shareholder meeting on Thursday.

articles.headline: Pfizer Asks F.D.A. to Authorize Its Covid-19 Vaccine for Children 5 to 11
articles.snippet: The agency has promised to move quickly on the request and  tentatively plans to meet on Oct. 26 to consider it. A decision could come soon after Halloween.
articles.abstract: The agency has promised to move quickly on the request and  tentatively plans to meet on Oct. 26 to consider it. A decision could come soon after Halloween.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pfizer and BioNTech asked federal regulators on Thursday to authorize emergency use of their coronavirus vaccine for children ages 5 to 11, a move that could help protect more than 28 million people in the United States.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: Bitcoin Preaches Financial Liberty. A Strongman Is Testing That Promise.
articles.snippet: As cryptocurrency enters global finance, an experiment in El Salvador could offer clues on whether it will bring a more libertarian economy or greater government control.
articles.abstract: As cryptocurrency enters global finance, an experiment in El Salvador could offer clues on whether it will bring a more libertarian economy or greater government control.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN MIGUEL, El Salvador — Bitcoin’s proponents dream of a financial system largely free of government meddling. But the first time that cryptocurrency became a national currency, it was imposed on an unwilling population by an increasingly authoritarian ruler using a secretive state-run system.
articles.byline: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Bryan Avelar and Ephrat Livni

articles.headline: With Masks On or Off, Schools Try to Find the New Normal
articles.snippet: Despite some turmoil, a vast majority of students have been in classrooms full-time and mostly uninterrupted this fall. Now, educators debate what’s next.
articles.abstract: Despite some turmoil, a vast majority of students have been in classrooms full-time and mostly uninterrupted this fall. Now, educators debate what’s next.
articles.lead_paragraph: When schools fully reopened, the Delta variant drove many worries: Would crowded classrooms run up infection rates? Would outbreaks keep many schools closed? Could there be a normal academic year — the first since the pandemic began?
articles.byline: By Dana Goldstein and Jacey Fortin
